--- Silk Road School <silk.road.school@...>
wrote:

> Bu hao, etc.?  Okay, let us in on the joke - my
> Chinese is even more limited
> than my Japanese.  (Which is essentially
> nonexistent, aside from some
> martial & historical terminology.)

"Bu hao" literally means "not good", but in usage it's
like "no thanks" in that situation. The rest I
said--"Wo bu xiang ni"--means "I don't want you". 

> On the other hand - as a clever segue into my quick
> note to James Wilson -
> my English is pretty good. 

Mr. Wilson has been notified that his posts will not
be let through unless he changes his opinion of
capital letters, punctuation, and proper spelling.
Three of his posts have been rejected with the
appropriate warnings. 

Please, people--it is not hard to hit the "shift" key.
Use it. Unless you are not a native English speaker or
are under the age of 10, there is no excuse.
